title: Aging Parent's Driving
cultural_context: Western aging independence values, family loyalty vs public safety
scenario_text: My 78-year-old father recently scraped another car in a parking lot and didn't notice. His reflexes are slowing down and last month he got confused and drove the wrong way on a one-way street. My siblings think I'm overreacting, but I'm terrified he'll hurt someone. I want to report him to the DMV so they'll make him retake his driving test, but my mom says it will "humiliate him" and "take away his independence." He's always been so proud of never having had an accident. AITA if I report him behind his back?
ai_response:
This is about weighing independence against safety - both matter deeply. Your father's pride and autonomy are real, but so is the risk to others. Rather than reporting behind his back, could you:

1. Frame it as care, not criticism: "Dad, I love you and want you driving safely as long as possible. Let's get your reflexes checked together."
2. Offer to help him prepare for a voluntary retest
3. Explore alternatives that preserve some independence (senior transport services, family driving schedule)

If he refuses and the danger is real, reporting may be necessary - but giving him agency in the process first respects his dignity while addressing the safety concern. Your siblings' denial doesn't change the reality of risk. This is hard because both values (autonomy and safety) are legitimate.
